Award.AwardTitle: Modeling Neural Processes as Analog Computations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports theoretical research into the brain as a computational system. It is motivated by developments in computational neuroscience where it has become increasingly clear that the sense in which the brain is computational is completely different from digital computation, the kind that predominates computer science. The researcher will develop an empirically-informed philosophical account of neural computation by drawing on current research in neuroscience and in historical research on analog computation. The results of this interdisciplinary project will contribute to the theoretical understanding of intriguing claims by psychologists and neuroscientists about the computational nature of the mind and brain. Findings are to be presented at conferences and workshops in computational neuroscience and in philosophy of science. The results of this research are to be published in an interdisciplinary monograph suitable for researchers in the cognitive science community. More broadly, the findings will be incorporated in courses to help students in both the sciences and humanities to make better sense of these kinds of claims.

Despite the early intellectual exchanges between neuroscience and the study of theoretical computation, it is no longer clear precisely what is meant by claims that the brain computes. Because the brain cannot be a digital computer of the kind whose theoretical underpinnings are found with the Turing Machine, claims that the brain is computational are either vacuous or metaphorical, or in need of a principled account of computation. This research project will provide such an account. It will serve to advance philosophy of neuroscience, and it will provide much-needed theoretical support to computational neuroscientists' claims that the brain is a computer, an intriguing idea that has yet to be carefully articulated. Current ideas about computation have largely ignored analog computation, which was once a thriving paradigm for computational practice. The rehabilitation of analog computation would add to our intellectual repertoire for thinking about other systems as computational.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Corey J. Maley has completed research, supported by an NSF Scholar Award, demonstrating that certain ways that the brain processes information is best understood as a kind of analog computation.

During his funding period, Corey participated in a number of conferences involving computer scientists, neuroscientists, philosophers, and psychologists. Most work in contemporary theoretical computer science does not concern analog computation, and the work that does exist mostly conceives of it as consisting merely of continuous–rather than discrete–variables. However, Corey's research into the history of analog computation shows that this is not always so. Instead, the fundamental idea behind analog computation is that the representations involved mirror what they represent. That mirroring can be either continuous or discrete.

For example, in an analog computer, a voltage might represent a variable: six volts represents six, and 34 volts represents 34. Often times, these voltages could vary continuously, but sometimes they only varied in, say, single-voltage steps, yet they were still analog.

In contrast, digital computers represent varibles by representing their individual digits. For example, a digital computer might represent the number 9 by using a series of voltages, where each individual voltage represents a single digit. The number in binary ("1001") would thus be represented by four voltages: one at five volts, another at zero, another at zero, and a last one at five.

The difference can be summarized by noticing that analog computation uses representations that take advantage of the physical nature of those representations, whereas digital computation uses representations that abstract from their physical nature. What matters for digital computation is that digits are represented physically; those digits, in turn, represent a variable. For analog computation, the physical representation is itself the variable.

When it comes to information processing in the brain, the ways that information is encoded seems to have much more in common with analog than digital computation. Neurons traffic in spikes, or action potentials. Originally, neuroscientists believed that these spikes were like binary pulses: they were either on or off. Now, however, new techniques have shown that this is too simple. Instead, neural spikes can have subtle differences in their shapes, which can have significant consequences. Furthermore, neurons can emit these spikes at different rates. These phenomena all allow for analog, rather than digital, information processing.

The extent to which this kind of neural information processing occurs will take more research in neuroscience. Additionally, there are many more questions that this research raises, including the extent to which higher-level brain structures combine these analog signals into more complex ones. However, this research gives new life to the idea that the brain can be understood in computational terms. While analog computation has fallen out of favor as a tool for scientific computing, it does seem to be the kind of computation that our brains have evolved to use.
